content.description:
Sustained interesting moves, starting tricky + fingery. 

  Up the face, then trend a bit left to finish at a small tree 8 ft left of the big protruding nose. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
content.protection:
For ideas to set up Top-Rope, see the Description of this Check Book sector . 

  Protection for Trad leading is unknown and likely inadequate.
content.location:
Face with vague small cracks which is just right just right of a 6-ft-wide blank bulge, and just left of an obvious 3-inch vertical crack which is under a big protruding nose up high. 

  --> See on these routes photos ... 

Left Side

Left - Dihedrals + Emerging Prominence

content.description:
Interest moves. 

  Diagonal left up the crack to meet the other crack coming from its left, then continue on the right crack up to the top. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.location:
The obvious crack whose bottom is about ten feet right from the obvious dark wide gully in the right half of the Check Book sector. This crack diagonals left to meet another crack, then continues up away from it. 

  --> See the Right Center routes Photo

content.description:
Up the crack to meet the other crack coming from its right, then continue on the crack diagonal to the left. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.location:
The obvious crack whose bottom is about six feet right from the obvious dark wide gully in the right half of the Check Book sector. This crack rises up to meet another crack, then angles away left from it. 

  --> See the Right Center routes Photo

content.description:
Climb partway up the dihedral, the finish on the overhang above the right face of the dihedral. 

  Tricky start, then hidden footholds in the overhang. 

  Easier if grab the little tree stump at the overhang. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.location:
Wider dihedral / open book with an overhang on its right side near the top. Bottom is a few feet right from a 6ft x 2ft detached block and just left of three other dihedrals.

content.description:
Start in the gully, up along the left side of the 3-ft high vertical torpedo ridge in the right half of the gully. Then up into the corner under overhang on the right side of the big nose. Finish onto the top of the nose. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Fun moves on positive holds.    . . (If only it were longer). 

  Start on the ground between the detached block and the left (SW) face of the pillar. Without using the detached block, go straight up the face to the top. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Balance needed in the low section, but strength needed for the finish. 

  Start with interesting moves up the face, then trend a bit left easier. Finish through roof at jaggies five feet right of the big protruding nose. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

Emerging Prominence

content.description:
Up the dihedral. Crux is exiting to the top of the cliff - (so if set the top anchor just below the top of the cliff, it makes climbers feel good about stopping without attempting that harder exit move). 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.location:
Wider dihedral / open book whose top is just right of an obvious overhang. It's the second from the left of four dihedrals, and the two dihedrals to its right are narrower. Near a jumble of fallen rocks at the high point of the ground at the base of the sector. 

  --> See on this routes photo ... Left Side

content.description:
Reach for the scoop to get to the crack system above, by the right edge of the Check Book wall. Finish to top of ramping corner-with-crack (the route Fleet Street) which comes up from the right. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Lots of fun interesting moves. 

  Start in the gully, up along the left side of the 3-ft high vertical torpedo ridge in the right half of the gully. Trend left underneath the big nose, then up to under the roof to the left of the big nose. Finish onto the top of the nose. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Starter investment for long-term future achievement.   Thoughtful scramble (alas too short). 

  Useful to get up to and down from the top of the Check Book wall. 

  Go up the gully, which gets narrower. Then before the top go right. 

warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Start in the gully, up along the right side of the 3-ft high vertical torpedo ridge in the right half of the gully. Next trend right-ward, then up to finish several feet right of jaggies in roof which are five feet right of big protruding nose, and several feet left of an overhanging top block. 

  Variation - "Exact Change" (5.8+): from the top of the vertical torpedo, continue straight up to finish through jaggies in the roof five right of the big protruding nose. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Fun moves in an interesting rock situation. If only this were longer. 

  Up the arete which forms the right edge of the obvious gully. Try to start as low as you can - (easier if start higher on the left side). 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

  Up the face between the obvious gully to its left and the obvious crack to its right -- without using the edge of the gully or the crack.

content.description:
Tricky to work out the Strategy.   Difficult for the climber to see one of the key holds. 

  Climb the left side of the gully (without using the center of the gully) and transition to the vague arete which forms the left edge of the gully. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Start with one foot on an exposed rock in the gap between the detached block and the left face of pillar. Climb the arete / ridge up to the obvious little roof at top, and straight over the roof. 

  Tricky sequence to get established on the arete is the crux. 

Warning: The rock on and around this route has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).

content.description:
Slab section which is about 600 feet (170 meters) right (east) from the Good Book wall . 

  Many short routes mainly for top-roping. Top anchor can be set up with a static line from trees above the cliff. 

  photos of route lines: 

Far Left

Left Side

Left - Dihedrals + Emerging Prominence

Emerging Prominence

Center + Right

Right Gully

Right End

Top Rope access: Could set up top-ropes by scrambling around the right (East) end, or by climbing the route EE Bond at the left (West) end of this sector. 

  This sector tends to be sheltered from winds from the West or NorthWest. 

warning: The rock on and around this cliff has not been climbed much yet, and much of the rock is still breakable and loose -- so the belayer and other people should stand far away from underneath the climber. 

  . . . (Lots of vegetation on this rock as of 2016. Be prepared when climbing to navigate around protruding trees and branches, and dealing with holds slippery with grass, lichen, moss, dirt).
